bestBHT.bht: Joseph of Arimathea took the body of Jesus down from the cross, wrapped it in a linen cloth he had bought, and laid it in his own tomb. The tomb, hewn out of a rock, had a stone rolled unto its door. While Mark does not mention the tomb being new, other Gospel writers do. Some scholars believe that this very tomb has been identified in Gordon's Calvary. Joseph's actions display his love and devotion to Jesus by ensuring that his body was properly cared for and laid to rest.

Henry Alford: Therefore it was not the first day of unleavened bread, which was one of sabbatical sanctity; as indeed the whole of this narrative shews, but such expressions as this more strikingly.
It is not said, but implied, both here and in Luke and John, that the tomb was his own—for how should he place the Body there otherwise?
The newness of the tomb is not mentioned here, but by the other three Evangelists.
Philip Schaff: And he bought a linen cloth. It has been argued from this purchase that the day was 'not the first day of unleavened bread, which was one of sabbatical sanctity.'
But in Leviticus 23:7, labor alone was forbidden on that day.
That the tomb belonged to Joseph is implied here, that it was new is omitted by Mark alone.
Archibald T. Robertson: The body of Jesus was wound in the linen cloth bought by Joseph and the hundred pounds of spices brought by Nicodemus for burying were placed in the folds of the linen and the linen was bound around the body by strips of cloth."
The perfect passive participle is from λατομος, a stonecutter (λως, stone, τεμνω, to cut).
Some modern scholars think that this very tomb has been identified in Gordon's Calvary north of the city.
John Gill: And he bought fine linen,.... That is, Joseph, as is expressed in the Vulgate Latin, Syriac, and Persic versions.
Took the body of Christ down from the cross; though, no doubt, with the assistance of others, or by others, and not he himself, at least not alone.
Laid him in a sepulchre, which was hewn out of a rock, and rolled a stone unto the door of the sepulchre.
John Wesley: He rolled a stone — By his servants. It was too large for him to roll himself.

bhtAttempts.bht: Joseph of Arimathea took the body of Jesus down from the cross and placed it in his own tomb, which was hewn out of a rock and had a stone rolled unto its door. The body was wrapped in a linen cloth that Joseph had bought, and Nicodemus brought a hundred pounds of spices to be placed with the body. While Mark does not explicitly mention that the tomb was new, the other three Gospel writers do. Some scholars have identified this tomb as the one located in Gordon's Calvary north of the city. Overall, Joseph's actions indicate his love and devotion to Jesus, ensuring that his body was properly cared for and laid to rest.

Joseph of Arimathea took the body of Jesus down from the cross, wrapped it in a linen cloth he had bought, and laid it in his own tomb. The tomb, hewn out of a rock, had a stone rolled unto its door. While Mark does not mention the tomb being new, other Gospel writers do. Some scholars believe that this very tomb has been identified in Gordon's Calvary. Joseph's actions display his love and devotion to Jesus by ensuring that his body was properly cared for and laid to rest.

Joseph of Arimathea, after taking the body of Jesus down from the cross, carefully wrapped it in a linen cloth that he had purchased. He placed the body in his own tomb, which was carved out of rock and had a stone rolled in front of it. While Mark does not explicitly mention the newness of the tomb, the other Gospel writers do. Some scholars have even suggested that this very tomb has been identified in Gordon's Calvary. Joseph's actions demonstrate his deep love and devotion to Jesus, ensuring that his body was properly cared for and laid to rest.

After taking the body of Jesus down from the cross, Joseph of Arimathea lovingly wrapped it in a linen cloth that he had purchased. He then placed the body in his own tomb, which was hewn out of rock and sealed with a stone. While Mark does not explicitly mention the tomb being new, the other Gospel writers do. Some scholars believe that this identified tomb is located in Gordon's Calvary. Joseph's actions reflect his deep devotion to Jesus, ensuring that his body was properly cared for and laid to rest.

Joseph of Arimathea took Jesus' body down from the cross and carefully wrapped it in a linen cloth that he had purchased. He then laid the body in his own tomb, which was hewn out of rock and sealed with a stone. While Mark does not explicitly mention the newness of the tomb, the other Gospel writers do. Some scholars believe this particular tomb is located in Gordon's Calvary. Joseph's actions exemplify his deep love and devotion to Jesus, ensuring proper care and burial for his body.
